a.g: O mankind, fear your Lord, who created you from one soul and created from it its mate and dispersed from both of them many men and women. And fear Allah, through whom you ask one another, and the wombs. Indeed Allah is ever, over you, an Observer.

Vol 4: Watchfulness and Self-Examination
And Allah the Exalted said: 'Indeed Allah was over you a Watcher (Raqib).' And Allah the Exalted said: 'And those who are to their trusts and their covenant caretakers (Ra'un), and those who are with their testimonies standing (Qa'imun).' And Ibn al-Mubarak said to a man: 'Observe (Raqib) Allah the Exalted,' and he asked him about its interpretation, so he said: 'Be always as if you see Allah, the Mighty, the Majestic.' And 'Abd al-Wahid ibn Zaid said: 'If my Master is a Watcher (Raqib) over me, then I do not care about anyone else.'

a.g: And give to the orphans their properties and do not substitute the defective [of your own] for the good [of theirs]. And do not consume their properties into your own. Indeed, that is ever a great sin.

And if you fear that you will not deal justly with the orphan girls, then marry those that please you of [other] women, two or three or four. But if you fear that you will not be just, then [marry only] one or those your right hand possesses. That is more suitable that you may not incline [to injustice].
And give the women [upon marriage] their [bridal] gifts graciously. But if they give up willingly to you anything of it, then take it in satisfaction and ease.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Self-Delusion
From that is their fatwa that when a woman absolves [her husband] from the dowry (sadaq), the husband is absolved between him and Allah the Exalted, and that is an error. Rather, the husband may mistreat the wife such that he constricts matters upon her with bad character, so she is compelled to seek deliverance and absolves the husband to be rid of him. This is an absolution not upon the contentment of the soul (nafs), and Allah the Exalted has said: 'Then if they are pleased to give you any of it, take it with good cheer and wholesome.' And the contentment of the soul (nafs) is not the contentment of the heart (qalb), for a person may will with his heart what his soul (nafs) is not content with, as he wills cupping with his heart but his soul (nafs) dislikes it. Rather, the contentment of the soul (nafs) is that it permits itself the absolution not from a necessity confronting it, such that when it is turned between two harms, it chooses the lesser of them. This is, in truth, seizure with internal compulsion.

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Book of Knowledge
And some scholar was asked about something and he did not answer, so the questioner said: Have you not heard the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) say: 'Whoever conceals beneficial knowledge will come on the Day of Resurrection bridled with a bridle of fire'? So he said: Leave the bridle and go, for if one comes who comprehends and I conceal it from him, then let him bridle me. Indeed Allah the Exalted has said: 'And do not give the foolish ones your wealth' as an indication that preserving knowledge from one who would corrupt it and harm it is more important, and injustice in giving to the undeserving is not less than injustice in withholding from the deserving: Should I scatter pearls among grazing livestock, then they become stored with a shepherd of sheep? For they have become ignorant of its value, so I am not the one who will adorn the beasts with it. If the Kindness of Allah the Gentle with His kindness and I encounter people worthy of knowledge and wisdom, I will spread what is beneficial and benefit mutually; otherwise it is stored with me and concealed. For whoever grants knowledge to the ignorant ones wastes it, and whoever withholds from the deserving ones has indeed been unjust.

a.g: And test the orphans [in their abilities] until they reach marriageable age. Then if you perceive in them sound judgement, release their property to them. And do not consume it excessively and quickly, [anticipating] that they will grow up. And whoever, [when acting as guardian], is self-sufficient should refrain [from taking a fee]; and whoever is poor - let him take according to what is acceptable. Then when you release their property to them, bring witnesses upon them. And sufficient is Allah as Accountant.
For men is a share of what the parents and close relatives leave, and for women is a share of what the parents and close relatives leave, be it little or much - an obligatory share.
And when [other] relatives and orphans and the needy are present at the [time of] division, then provide for them [something] out of the estate and speak to them words of appropriate kindness.
And let those [executors and guardians] fear [injustice] as if they [themselves] had left weak offspring behind and feared for them. So let them fear Allah and speak words of appropriate justice.
Indeed, those who devour the property of orphans unjustly are only consuming into their bellies fire. And they will be burned in a Blaze.

And He (Allah), the Exalted, said: 'Indeed, those who consume the wealth of the orphans unjustly, they only consume fire into their bellies, and they will burn in a Blaze.' And He, the Exalted, said: 'O you who have believed, fear Allah and give up what remains [due to you] of interest, if you should be believers.' Then He said: 'And if you do not, then be informed of a war from Allah and His Messenger.' Then He said: 'But if you repent, you may have your principal.' Then He said: 'And whoever returns to [dealing in interest] - those are the companions of the Fire; they will abide therein eternally.' He made the consumer of interest at the beginning of the matter announcing war from Allah, and at its end exposed to the Fire. And the verses that have come regarding the lawful (Halal) and the unlawful (Haram) are innumerable.

a.g: Allah instructs you concerning your children: for the male, what is equal to the share of two females. But if there are [only] daughters, two or more, for them is two thirds of one's estate. And if there is only one, for her is half. And for one's parents, to each one of them is a sixth of his estate if he left children. And if he had brothers [or sisters], for his mother is a sixth, after any bequest he [may have] made or debt. Your parents or your children - you know not which of them are nearest to you in benefit. [These shares are] an obligation [imposed] by Allah. Indeed, Allah is ever Knowing and Wise.

For whoever is overcome by sadness or longing or regret, how can his state be suited by the saying of Allah the Exalted: 'Allah instructs you concerning your children: for the male is like the share of two females' and His saying: 'And those who accuse chaste women' and likewise all the verses that contain clarification of the rulings of inheritance and divorce and prescribed punishments and others. Rather, what moves what is in the Heart (Qalb) is what suits it. And the verses are indeed placed by the poets as expression through them of the states of the Heart (Qalb), so there is no need for exertion in understanding the state from them. Yes, whoever is overcome by a dominant, overwhelming state that leaves no room in him for anything else, and with him is alertness and penetrating intelligence through which he perceives the distant meanings from the words, indeed his spiritual ecstasy (Wajd) may emerge upon everything heard, like one to whom occurs upon mention of the saying of Allah the Exalted: 'Allah instructs you concerning your children: for the male is like the share of two females' the state of death necessitating the will, and that every human being inevitably leaves behind his wealth and his children, and they are his two beloved things from the worldly life, so he leaves one of the beloved for the other and abandons them both, so fear and distress overcome him. Or he hears the remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah in His saying: 'Allah instructs you concerning your children' and he is astonished by the mere Name from what precedes and follows it. Or occurs to him the mercy of Allah upon His servants and His compassion by undertaking the division of their inheritances Himself, looking after them in their life and their death, so he says: 'If He looks after our children after our death, then we do not doubt that He looks after us,' so from that arises the state of hope and that bequeaths to him gladness and joy. Or occurs to him from His saying the Exalted: 'for the male is like the share of two females' the preference of the male by him being a man over the female, and that the excellence in the Hereafter is for men whom neither commerce nor sale distracts from the remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah, and that whoever is distracted by other than Allah the Exalted from Allah the Exalted, then he is from the females, not from the men, in reality, so he fears that he may be veiled or delayed in the bliss of the Hereafter as the female was delayed in the worldly wealth. So the likes of this may move the spiritual ecstasy (Wajd), but for one in whom are two descriptions: one of them a dominant, all-encompassing, overwhelming state, and the other profound perception and complete, thorough alertness for alerting through the near matters to the distant meanings, and that is among what is rare. Therefore, for that reason, he resorts to singing, which is words suitable for the states, so that the agitation hastens.

Where does it suit his state the saying of the Exalted: 'Allah instructs you concerning your children: for the male is like the share of two females. But if there are [only] daughters, two or more, for them is two thirds of one's estate. And if there is only one, for her is half. And for one's parents, to each one of them is a sixth of his estate if he left children. But if he had no children and the parents [alone] inherit from him, then for his mother is one third. And if he had brothers [or sisters], for his mother is a sixth, after any bequest he [may have] made or debt. Your parents or your children - you know not which of them are nearest to you in benefit. [These shares are] an obligation [imposed] by Allah. Indeed, Allah is ever Knowing and Wise.' (Quran 4:11) and His saying: 'And those who accuse chaste women...' and likewise all the verses that contain clarification of the rulings of inheritance, divorce, prescribed punishments, and others. Rather, what moves what is in the Heart (Qalb) is what suits it. And the verses, the poets only place them as expression through them of the states of the Heart (Qalb), so there is no need in understanding the state from them to forced effort. Yes, whoever is overcome by a dominating, overwhelming state that leaves no room in him for anything else, and with him is alertness and penetrating intelligence through which he perceives the distant meanings from the words, then his spiritual state (Wajd) may emerge upon everything heard, like one to whom occurs upon the mention of His saying: 'Allah instructs you concerning your children...' the state of death necessitating the will, and that every human being inevitably leaves behind his wealth and his children, and they are his two beloved things from the worldly life, so he leaves one of the two beloved for the second and abandons them both, so fear and distress overcome him. Or he hears the mention (Dhikr) of Allah in His saying: 'Allah instructs you concerning your children...' so he is astonished by the mere Name from what precedes and follows it. Or occurs to him the mercy of Allah upon His servants and His compassion by undertaking the division of their inheritances Himself, looking after them in their life and their death, so he says: 'If He looks after our children after our death, then we have no doubt that He looks after us,' so from that arises the state of hope and that bequeaths him gladness and joy. Or occurs to him from His saying: 'for the male is like the share of two females' the preference of the male by him being a man over the female, and that the excellence in the Hereafter is for men whom neither commerce nor sale distracts from the remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah, and that whoever is distracted by other than Allah, the Exalted, from Allah, the Exalted, then he is from the females, not from the men, in reality, so he fears that he may be veiled or delayed in the bliss of the Hereafter as the female was delayed in the worldly wealth. So the likes of this may move the spiritual state (Wajd), but for one in whom are two descriptions: one of them is a dominating, all-encompassing, overwhelming state, and the other is profound perception and complete, perfect alertness for alerting through the near matters to the distant meanings, and that is rare. Therefore, for that reason, he resorts to singing which is words suitable for the states so that their agitation hastens.

a.g: And for you is half of what your wives leave if they have no child. But if they have a child, for you is one fourth of what they leave, after any bequest they [may have] made or debt. And for the wives is one fourth if you leave no child. But if you leave a child, then for them is an eighth of what you leave, after any bequest you [may have] made or debt. And if a man or woman leaves neither ascendants nor descendants but has a brother or a sister, then for each one of them is a sixth. But if they are more than two, they share a third, after any bequest which was made or debt, as long as there is no detriment [caused]. [This is] an ordinance from Allah, and Allah is Knowing and Forbearing.

These are the limits [set by] Allah, and whoever obeys Allah and His Messenger will be admitted by Him to gardens [in Paradise] under which rivers flow, abiding eternally therein; and that is the great attainment.

a.g: Those who commit unlawful sexual intercourse of your women - bring against them four [witnesses] from among you. And if they testify, confine the guilty women to houses until death takes them or Allah ordains for them [another] way.
And the two who commit it among you, dishonor them both. But if they repent and correct themselves, leave them alone. Indeed, Allah is ever Accepting of repentance and Merciful.

The repentance accepted by Allah is only for those who do wrong in ignorance [or carelessness] and then repent soon after. It is those to whom Allah will turn in forgiveness, and Allah is ever Knowing and Wise.

But repentance is not [accepted] of those who [continue to] do evil deeds up until, when death comes to one of them, he says, "Indeed, I have repented now," or of those who die while they are disbelievers. For them We have prepared a painful punishment.

At that point, his sight is cut off from the world and its people, and the door of repentance (Tawbah) is closed before him, and regret (Hasarah) and remorse (Nadamah) surround him. And the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: 'The repentance (Tawbah) of the servant is accepted as long as he has not reached the death rattle (Ghargharah).' And Mujahid said regarding His (Exalted is He) statement: 'And repentance (Tawbah) is not for those who do evil deeds until, when death comes to one of them, he says, "Indeed, I have repented now."' He said: When he witnesses the messengers, then at that time the page of the face of the Angel of Death (Malak al-Mawt) becomes apparent to him, so do not ask about the taste of the bitterness (Murarah) of death and its distress (Kurbah) upon the succession of its agonies (Sakarat). And for that reason, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used to say: 'O Allah, make easy for Muhammad the agonies (Sakarat) of death.'

For if you dislike them - perhaps you dislike a thing and Allah makes therein much good.

Indeed, the second refinement [adab] is to maintain excellent character [husn al-khuluq] with them, and to bear patiently the harm [adha] that comes from them, out of compassion for them, due to the deficiency of their intellect [aql]. And Allah, the Exalted, has said: "And live with them in kindness [ma'ruf]." And He said, in magnifying their right [haqq]: "And they have taken from you a solemn covenant [mithaq ghaliz]." And He said: "And the companion [sahib] at your side." It is said this refers to the woman. And the final words the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, counseledâ€”three matters he would speak until his tongue grew heavy and his speech became faintâ€”he would say: "The prayer [as-salah], the prayer [as-salah]. And those whom your right hands possess [ma malakat aymanukum]â€”do not burden them with what they cannot bear. Allah, Allah, concerning women [nisaa'], for indeed they are captives [awan] in your hands." Meaning, they are captives; you have taken them by the trust [amanah] of Allah, and you have made lawful their private parts by the word [kalimah] of Allah.

a.g: But if you want to replace one wife with another and you have given one of them a great amount [in gifts], do not take [back] from it anything. Would you take it in injustice and manifest sin?
And how could you take it while you have gone in unto each other and they have taken from you a solemn covenant?
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 2: Etiquette of Marriage
The second etiquette is good character (Husn al-Khuluq) with them and bearing harm from them out of mercy upon them due to the deficiency of their intellects. And Allah the Exalted said: 'And live with them in kindness (Ma'ruf).' And He said in magnifying their rights: 'And they have taken from you a solemn covenant (Mithaqan Ghalidhan).' And He said: 'And the companion by the side (al-Sahib bil-Janb).' It is said she is the woman. And the last thing the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, enjoined was three things he would speak until his tongue stammered and his speech became faint. He would say: 'The prayer (al-Salah), the prayer, and what your right hands possess (Ma Malakat Aymanukum), do not burden them with what they cannot bear. Allah, Allah, for indeed they are captives (Awan) in your hands.' Meaning captives, you have taken them by the trust (Amanah) of Allah and you have made lawful their private parts by the word (Kalimah) of Allah.

a.g: And do not marry those [women] whom your fathers married, except what has already occurred. Indeed, it was an immorality and hateful [to Allah] and was evil as a way.

Prohibited to you [for marriage] are your mothers, your daughters, your sisters, your father's sisters, your mother's sisters, your brother's daughters, your sister's daughters, your [milk] mothers who nursed you, your sisters through nursing, your wives' mothers, and your step-daughters under your guardianship [born] of your wives unto whom you have gone in. But if you have not gone in unto them, there is no sin upon you. And [also prohibited are] the wives of your sons who are from your [own] loins, and that you take [in marriage] two sisters simultaneously, except for what has already occurred. Indeed, Allah is ever Forgiving and Merciful.

And [also prohibited to you are all] married women except those your right hands possess. [This is] the decree of Allah upon you. And lawful to you are [all others] beyond these, [provided] that you seek them [in marriage] with [gifts from] your property, desiring chastity, not unlawful sexual intercourse. So for whatever you enjoy [of marriage] from them, give them their due compensation as an obligation. And there is no blame upon you for what you mutually agree to beyond the obligation. Indeed, Allah is ever Knowing and Wise.

And whoever among you cannot [find] the means to marry free, believing women, then [he may marry] from those whom your right hands possess of believing slave girls. And Allah is most knowing about your faith. You [believers] are of one another. So marry them with the permission of their people and give them their due compensation according to what is acceptable. [They should be] chaste, neither [of] those who commit unlawful intercourse randomly nor those who take [secret] lovers. But once they are sheltered in marriage, if they should commit adultery, then for them is half the punishment for free [unmarried] women. This [allowance] is for him among you who fears sin, but to be patient is better for you. And Allah is Forgiving and Merciful.

Allah wants to accept your repentance, but those who follow [their] passions want you to digress [into] a great deviation.

a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 2: Etiquette of Marriage
Indeed, concerning the meaning of His, the Exalted's, statement, "And man was created weak [da'if]," 'Ikrimah and Mujahid said it means he cannot be patient regarding women. And this matter, while it is suitable to be an impetus for both lives [al-hayatayn] as preceded, is the strongest instrument [ala] of Satan [al-shaytan] against the children of Adam. And to this He, peace and blessings be upon him, alluded with his saying, "I have not seen from those deficient in intellect [aql] and religion [din] more overwhelming for possessors of sound minds than you." And that is only due to the raging of desire [shahwah]. And this is a dominant affliction [baliah]; when it rages, neither intellect [aql] nor religion [din] can resist it.

a.g: O you who have believed, do not consume one another's wealth unjustly but only [in lawful] business by mutual consent. And do not kill yourselves [or one another]. Indeed, Allah is to you ever Merciful.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 2: Etiquette of Eating
And Allah the Exalted has commanded eating the good (al-Tayyib), which is the lawful (al-Halal), and He placed the prohibition of eating through falsehood (al-Batil) before killing, magnifying the matter of the forbidden (al-Haram) and exalting the blessing of the lawful (al-Halal). So He the Exalted said: 'O you who have believed, do not consume your properties among yourselves unjustly (bi al-Batil)' until His saying 'and do not kill yourselves' the verse. So the foundation in food is its being good (Tayyib), and it is from the obligations (al-Fara'id) and foundations of the religion (Usool al-Deen).

If you avoid the major sins which you are forbidden, We will remove from you your lesser sins and admit you to a noble entrance [into Paradise].

a.g: And for all, We have made heirs to what is left by parents and relatives. And to those whom your oaths have bound [to you] - give them their share. Indeed Allah is ever, over all things, a Witness.

Men are in charge of women by [right of] what Allah has given one over the other and what they spend [for maintenance] from their wealth. So righteous women are devoutly obedient, guarding in [the husband's] absence what Allah would have them guard. But those [wives] from whom you fear arrogance - [first] advise them; [then if they persist], forsake them in bed; and [finally], strike them. But if they obey you [once more], seek no means against them. Indeed, Allah is ever Exalted and Grand.

And Allah has named men (Qawwamoona 'ala al-nisa') and named the husband a master (Sayyid) as He said, Exalted is He: (And they found her master at the door). So if the master becomes subjugated, then he has (exchanged the favor of Allah for disbelief). And the Soul (Nafs) of the woman is like your own soul; if you loosen its rein a little, it will bolt with you for a long time, and if you slacken its bridle for a moment, it will drag you by the arm, and if you curb it and tighten your hand upon it in the place of severity, you will possess it.

The twelfth [chapter] is on divorce, and know that it is permissible but it is the most detested of permissible things to Allah the Exalted. It is only permissible when there is no harm without right, and whenever he divorces her, he has harmed her. It is not permissible to harm another except due to a transgression from her side or a necessity from his side. Allah the Exalted said: 'Then if they obey you, do not seek a way against them' (Quran 4:34), meaning do not seek a pretext for separation. And if his father dislikes her, let him divorce her. Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, said: 'I had a wife whom I loved, and my father disliked her and ordered me to divorce her. So I consulted the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and he said: O Ibn Umar, divorce your wife.' This indicates that the right of the parent takes precedence, but a parent who dislikes her without a corrupt purpose, like Umar. And whenever she harms her husband and exposes [secrets] about his family, she is a transgressor. Likewise, whenever she is of bad character or corrupt in religion. Ibn Mas'ud said regarding Allah's statement 'nor should they leave except that they commit a clear immorality' (Quran 65:1): whenever she exposes about his family and harms her husband, that is an immorality. This is intended regarding the waiting period, but it alerts to the intended meaning. And if the harm is from the husband, she may ransom herself by giving wealth. It is disliked for the man to take from her more than what he gave, for that is injustice to her and oppression upon her and trading upon the private part. Allah said: 'There is no blame upon them for what she gives up to ransom herself' (Quran 2:229). Returning what he took or less is suitable for the ransom. If she asks for divorce without any wrong, she is sinful. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Any woman who asks her husband for divorce without any wrong, she will not smell the fragrance of Paradise.' In another wording: 'Paradise is forbidden to her.' And in another wording: he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'The women who seek khul' are the hypocrites.'

The fourth is that he should not expand in jest [dahik] and good character [husn al-khuluq] and agreement by following her whim [hawa] to the point that it corrupts her character and causes his awe [hayba] before her to fall away completely. Rather, he should observe moderation [i'tidal] in it. So he does not abandon awe and sternness whenever he sees a wrong [munkar], nor does he open the door to assisting in wrongs at all. Rather, whenever he sees what contradicts the Sacred Law [shar'] and manly virtue [muru'a], he should show displeasure and be vexed. Al-Hasan said, "By God, no man obeys his wife in what she desires [hawa] except that God casts him into the Fire." And 'Umar, may God be pleased with him, said, "Oppose women, for in opposing them is blessing [baraka]." And it has been said, "Consult them and oppose them." And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said, "Wretched is the slave of the wife." He only said that because if he obeys her in her whim [hawa], then he is her slave, and he is wretched. For God made him the master [malik] of the woman, but he made her the master of himself. So he has reversed the matter and overturned the case, and he has obeyed Satan when he said, "And I will command them so they will change the creation of God." For the right of the man is to be followed, not a follower. And God has named men "maintainers [qawwamun] over women," and He named the husband a master [sayyid], as He, the Exalted, said, "And they found her master [sayyidaha] at the door." So if the master becomes subjugated, then he has "exchanged the favor of God for disbelief." And the soul [nafs] of the woman is like your own soul [nafs]. If you loosen its rein a little, it will bolt with you for a long time. If you slacken its bridle a bit, it will drag you an arm's length. If you curb it and tighten your hand upon it in the place of severity, you will master it. Al-Shafi'i, may God be pleased with him, said, "Three, if you honor them, they will disgrace you, and if you disgrace them, they will honor you: the woman, the servant, and the Nabatean." He meant by this that if you offer pure honor and do not mix your harshness with your gentleness and your roughness with your kindness. And in sum, by justice [adl] the heavens and the earth stand. So everything that exceeds its limit reverts to its opposite. Therefore, you should take the path of moderation [iqtisad] in opposition and agreement, and follow the truth [haqq] in all of that, to be safe from their evil. For "their guile is great," and their evil is widespread, and what predominates in them is bad character and weakness of intellect. And that is not set right from them except by a kind of gentleness mixed with governance [siyasa].

And indeed Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) sent an arbitrator to a couple, and he returned without reconciling their matter, so he struck him with the whip and said: 'Indeed Allah the Exalted says: "If they desire reconciliation, Allah will reconcile between them."' So the man returned and improved his intention and was gentle with them, and he reconciled between them.

Vol 2: Etiquette of Marriage
And the companion by your side [wa al-sahib bi al-janb]. It is said: she is the woman. And the last of what the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, enjoined were three things he would speak of until his tongue faltered and his speech became faint. He would say: "The prayer [al-salat], the prayer [al-salat], and those whom your right hands possess [ma malakat aymanukum]. Do not burden them with what they cannot bear. God [Allah], God [Allah], for indeed they are captives [awan] in your hands." Meaning: captives you have taken by the trust of God [amanat Allah], and you have made lawful their private parts by the word of God [kalimat Allah].

And Al-Hasan ibn Ali (may Allah be pleased with them both) passed by a group of the poor (Masakeen) who ask people on the road, and they had spread out crumbs on the ground in the sand and they were eating, while he was on his mule. He greeted them, and they said to him: 'Come to lunch, O son of the daughter of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him).' He presented to them the finest food and sat eating with them.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Miserliness
Explanation of the condemnation of miserliness. Allah the Exalted said: "And whoever is protected from the greed (Shuh) of his Soul (Nafs), then those are the successful ones." And He the Exalted said: "And let not those who are miserly with what Allah has given them of His bounty think it is good for them; rather, it is bad for them. They will be made to wear what they were miserly with on the Day of Resurrection." And He the Exalted said: "Those who are miserly and command people to miserliness and conceal what Allah has given them of His bounty." And he (the Prophet) ï·º said: "Beware of greed (Shuh), for it destroyed those before you; it drove them to shed their blood and make lawful what was forbidden to them." [75] And he ï·º said: "Beware of greed (Shuh), for it called those before you and they shed their blood, and it called them and they made lawful what was forbidden to them, and it called them and they severed their kinship ties." [76] And he ï·º said: "The miser (Bakhil), the deceitful, and the treacherous with bad character will not enter Paradise." [77] And in a narration: "Nor the tyrant." And in a narration: "Nor the one who reminds of his favors." And he ï·º said: "Three destructive things: obeyed greed (Shuh), followed desire (Hawa), and self-admiration of a person." [78] And he ï·º said: "Indeed, Allah hates three: the old fornicator, the miser (Bakhil) who reminds of his favors, and the poor arrogant." [79] And he ï·º said: "The example of the spender and the miser (Bakhil) is like two men wearing iron shirts from their chests to their collarbones. As for the spender, he does not spend anything except that it expands or increases over his skin until it hides his fingertips. As for the miser (Bakhil), he does not intend to spend anything except that it shrinks and sticks to every ring of his until it takes hold of his collarbones, and he widens it but it does not widen." [80] And he ï·º said: "Two traits do not gather in a believer: miserliness (Bukhl) and bad character." [81] And he ï·º said: "O Allah, I seek refuge in You from miserliness (Bukhl), and I seek refuge in You from cowardice, and I seek refuge in You from being returned to the most despicable age." [82] And he ï·º said: "Beware of oppression, for oppression is darknesses on the Day of Resurrection, and beware of obscenity, for Allah does not love the obscene nor the one who acts obscenely,"

Indeed, Allah does not do injustice, [even] as much as an atom's weight; while if there is a good deed, He multiplies it and gives from Himself a great reward.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Love, Longing, and Intimacy
Whoever's love in the worldly life is his hope for the bliss of Paradise, the Houris, and palaces, is granted Paradise to settle wherever he wishes, playing with the youths and enjoying the women; there his pleasure ends in the Hereafter because each person in love is given what his Soul (Nafs) desires and what delights his eye. And whoever's aim is the Lord of the Abode and Owner of the Kingdom, and nothing overcomes him except his love with sincerity (Ikhlas) and truthfulness (Sidq), is placed "in a seat of truth near a Sovereign Omnipotent." So the righteous ones roam in the gardens and enjoy bliss in the Paradises with the Houris and youths, while the near ones (Muqarrabun) are constant in the Presence (Hadrah), devoted with their gaze upon it, belittling the bliss of the Paradises compared to a particle of it, for some people are preoccupied with satisfying the desires of the belly and private parts, and for companionship there are other people. Therefore, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Most of the people of Paradise are the simple-minded, and the highest levels (Illiyyun) are for those of intellect." And when understandings fell short of grasping the meaning of the highest levels (Illiyyun), He magnified its matter, saying: "And what will make you know what the highest levels (Illiyyun) are?" just as Allah the Exalted said: "The Striking Calamity - what is the Striking Calamity? And what will make you know what the Striking Calamity is?" And among them is that one is in his love fearful, diminished under awe (Haybah) and veneration (Ta'zim), and it may be thought that fear opposes love, but it is not so; rather, perceiving greatness necessitates awe just as perceiving beauty necessitates love, and specifically.

Vol 4: Intention, Sincerity, and Truthfulness
And the reports are not free from contradiction in this matter, and what becomes clear regarding itâ€”and knowledge is with Allahâ€”is to look at the measure of the strength of the motive. If the religious motive is equal to the soul (Nafs) motive, they counterbalance and cancel each other out, and the action becomes neither for nor against him. And if the motive of ostentation (Riya) is more dominant and stronger, it is not beneficial, and moreover, it is harmful and leads to punishmentâ€”yes, the punishment in it is lighter than the punishment of the action that was purely for ostentation and not mixed with any trace of drawing near (to Allah). And if the intention of drawing near (to Allah) is more dominant relative to the other motive, then he has reward according to what remains of the strength of the religious motive. And this is due to His saying, the Exalted: 'So whoever does an atom's weight of good will see it, and whoever does an atom's weight of evil will see it' (Quran 99:7-8), and His saying, the Exalted: 'Indeed, Allah does not do injustice to the weight of an atom. And if there is a good deed, He multiplies it and gives from Himself a great reward' (Quran 4:40). So it is not fitting that the intention of good be wasted; rather, if it is dominant over the intention of ostentation, the portion that equals it is nullified, and the increase remains. And if it is overcome, something of the punishment of the corrupt intention falls away because of it.

Know that the proofs for this are many. Among them is His statement, the Exalted: 'And establish prayer for My remembrance (Dhikr)' (Taha: 14). Indeed, Allah the Exalted has said: **"Indeed, Allah does not forgive association with Him [shirk], but He forgives what is less than that for whom He wills."** [Chapter on the Vastness of Allah's Mercy] We conclude the book with a chapter on the vastness of the mercy [rahma] of Allah the Exalted, as an act of optimism [tafa'ul] in that, for indeed (the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, loved good omens), and we have no deeds by which we may hope for forgiveness, so we follow the example of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, in optimism and we hope that He seals our end with good in this world [dunya] and the Hereafter, just as we concluded the book by mentioning His mercy [rahma]. For indeed Allah the Exalted has said: **"Indeed, Allah does not forgive association with Him [shirk], but He forgives what is less than that for whom He wills."** And He the Exalted said: **"Say, 'O My servants who have transgressed against themselves [by sinning], do not despair of the mercy [rahma] of Allah. Indeed, Allah forgives all sins. Indeed, it is He who is the Forgiving, the Merciful.'"** And He the Exalted said: **"And whoever does an evil or wrongs himself then seeks forgiveness of Allah will find Allah Forgiving and Merciful."** And we seek forgiveness [istighfar] from Allah the Exalted for every slip of the foot or transgression of the pen in this book of ours and in all our books. And we seek His forgiveness for our words which our actions do not match. And we seek His forgiveness for what we claimed and displayed of knowledge [ilm] and insight [basira] into the religion of Allah the Exalted while being deficient in it. And we seek His forgiveness for every knowledge [ilm] and deed we intended for His Noble Countenance, then something else became mixed with it. And we seek His forgiveness for every promise we made to ourselves, then fell short in fulfilling. And we seek His forgiveness for every blessing [ni'ma] He bestowed upon us, then we employed it in disobedience to Him. And we seek His forgiveness for every explicit and implicit mention of the deficiency of a deficient one or the shortcoming of one who fell short, with which we were characterized. And we seek His forgiveness for every fleeting thought that called us to affectation and pretense, to adorn ourselves before people in a book we penned, or speech we composed, or knowledge [ilm] we imparted or received. And we hope, after seeking forgiveness for all of thatâ€”for us and for whoever reads this book of ours or writes it or hears itâ€”that we are honored with forgiveness [maghfira] and mercy [rahma] and pardon for all sins, outward and inward. For generosity is immense, mercy [rahma] is vast, and bounty upon all kinds of creation is overflowing. And we are a creation from the creation of Allah, the Mighty and Majestic; we have no means to Him except His favor and His generosity. For indeed the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: **(Indeed, Allah the Exalted has one hundred mercies [rahma]; He sent down from them a single mercy [rahma] between the jinn, mankind, birds, beasts, and creeping things. Through it they show affection and through it they show mercy to one another. And He withheld ninety-nine mercies [rahma] by which He will show mercy to His servants on the Day of Resurrection.)** And it is narrated that **(When the Day of Resurrection comes, Allah the Exalted will bring out a book from beneath the Throne, in it is: 'Indeed My mercy [rahma] has preceded My wrath, and I am the Most Merciful of the merciful.' Then He will bring out of the Fire the like of the people of Paradise.)** And the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: **(Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, will appear to us on the Day of Resurrection smiling, and He will say: 'Receive glad tidings, O community of Muslims, for there is not one of you except that I have placed in the Fire in his place a Jew or a Christian.')**

Indeed, the first aspect [al-wajh al-awwal], which does not rely on confronting doubt, is the precaution [al-ihtiraz] from certainty [al-jazm] for fear of what it contains of self-praise [tazkiyat al-nafs]. Allah, the Exalted, says: "So do not claim purity for yourselves [fa la tuzakku anfusakum]" (4:49). And He says: "Have you not seen those who claim purity for themselves [alladhina yuzakkuuna anfusahum]?" (4:49). And the Exalted says: "See how they invent lies about Allah" (4:50). And it was said to a wise man, "What is ugly truthfulness [al-sidq al-qabih]?" He said, "A person's praise of himself." And faith [al-iman] is among the highest attributes of glory [al-majd], and certainty [al-jazm] is absolute self-praise [tazkiyah mutlaqah]. And the formula of exception [sighat al-istithna'] is as if it is a burden for one who knows self-praise [al-tazkiyah]; just as it is said to a person, "You are a doctor, or a jurist, or an exegete," and he says, "Yes, if Allah wills [in sha' Allah]," not in the manner of casting doubt [al-tashkik] but to remove himself from praising himself. Thus, the formula is the formula of hesitation [al-taraddud] and weakening [al-tad'if] of the report itself, and its meaning is the necessary weakening [al-tad'if al-lazim] from the necessary concomitants [lawazim] of the report, which is self-praise [al-tazkiyah]. And by this interpretation [ta'wil], if one were asked about a description of blame [wasf dham], it would not be proper to make an exception.

Those are the ones whom Allah has cursed; and he whom Allah curses - never will you find for him a helper.

a.g: O you who have believed, obey Allah and obey the Messenger and those in authority among you. And if you disagree over anything, refer it to Allah and the Messenger, if you should believe in Allah and the Last Day. That is the best [way] and best in result.

Have you not seen those who claim to have believed in what was revealed to you, [O Muhammad], and what was revealed before you? They wish to refer legislation to Taghut, while they were commanded to reject it; and Satan wishes to lead them far astray.
And when it is said to them, "Come to what Allah has revealed and to the Messenger," you see the hypocrites turning away from you in aversion.
So how [will it be] when disaster strikes them because of what their hands have put forth and then they come to you swearing by Allah, "We intended nothing but good conduct and accommodation."
Those are the ones of whom Allah knows what is in their hearts, so turn away from them but admonish them and speak to them a far-reaching word.

And We did not send any messenger except to be obeyed by permission of Allah. And if, when they wronged themselves, they had come to you, [O Muhammad], and asked forgiveness of Allah and the Messenger had asked forgiveness for them, they would have found Allah Accepting of repentance and Merciful.

Then he returns and stands at the head of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) between the grave and the pillar today, faces the Qiblah, praises Allah the Exalted and glorifies Him, and increases in sending prayers upon the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). Then he says: O Allah, You have said and Your saying is the Truth - 'And if they, when they wronged their souls (Nafs), had come to you and asked forgiveness of Allah and the Messenger had asked forgiveness for them, they would have found Allah Accepting of repentance (Tawwab), Merciful (Rahim).' - O Allah, we have heard Your saying and obeyed Your command, and we have sought Your Prophet, interceding through him to You for our sins and what has burdened our backs from our burdens, repenting (Ta'ib) from our slips, confessing our mistakes and shortcomings. So accept our repentance (Tawbah), O Allah, and let Your Prophet intercede for us, and elevate us through his station with You and his right upon You. O Allah, forgive the Emigrants (Muhajirun) and the Helpers (Ansar), and forgive us and our brothers who preceded us in faith. O Allah, do not make this the last visit to the grave of Your Prophet and Your sanctuary, O Most Merciful of the merciful.

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Invocations and Supplications
Indeed, if you say: "What benefit is there in supplication [du'a], when the decree [qada'] cannot be turned back?" Then know that among the decrees is the repelling of affliction [bala'] through supplication. So supplication is a cause [sabab] for repelling affliction and for attracting mercy [rahma], just as the shield is a cause for repelling the arrow, and water is a cause for the emergence of plants from the earth. And just as the shield pushes against the arrow and they repel each other, so too do supplication and affliction contend with one another. And it is not a condition of affirming the decree [qada'] of God, the Exalted, that one should not carry a weapon, for He, the Exalted, has said: "Take your precaution." Nor is it that one should not water the earth after scattering the seed, saying, "If the decree [qada'] preceded it with growth, the seed will grow, and if it did not precede it, it will not grow." And the arranging of the details of the effects according to the details of the causes, in gradual stages and by measure [taqdir], is the Ordainment [al-qadr]. And He who ordained [qaddara] the good ordained it with a cause, and He who ordained [qaddara] the evil ordained a cause for its repelling. So there is no contradiction between these matters for one whose insight [basira] has been opened.

This indicates that whoever is afflicted with a town where sins abound and good decreases has no excuse to remain there, but rather should emigrate. Indeed, the ultimate reality is that asceticism [zuhd] is an expression of aversion to all the desires [huzuz] of the self [nafs]. Whenever one is averse to the desires of the self, he is averse to remaining in the world [dunya], and his hope [amal] is inevitably shortened. For he only desires to remain in order to enjoy, and he desires perpetual enjoyment through desiring permanence; for whoever desires a thing desires its permanence. And there is no meaning to the love of life except the love of the permanence of what exists or is possible in this life. So when he is averse to it, he does not desire it. And for this reason, when fighting was prescribed for them, "They said, 'Our Lord, why have You prescribed for us fighting? If only You had postponed it for us for a short time.'" So the Most High said: "Say, 'The enjoyment of the world is little.'" That is: You do not desire to remain except for the enjoyment of the world. Thus, at that point, the ascetics [zahidun] became manifest, and the condition of the hypocrites was unveiled. And the indication to defining the baseness of the world is in His saying, the Most High: "Say, 'The enjoyment of the world is little.'"

Know that the one who harms is naturally hated, and if someone harms you, you cannot help but generally dislike them. If a blessing is facilitated for them, you cannot help but resent it for them until the good state of your enemy and their bad state become equal to you. Rather, you continuously perceive in the soul (Nafs) a distinction between them, and Satan continuously contends with you toward envy (Hasad) for them. But if that becomes strong in you until it incites you to manifest envy (Hasad) by word or action such that it is known from your outward appearance through your voluntary actions, then you are an envious sinner by your envy (Hasad). And if you completely restrain your outward appearance, yet in your inner self you desire the removal of the blessing and there is no aversion in your soul (Nafs) to this state, then you are also an envious sinner, because envy (Hasad) is an attribute of the heart (Qalb), not an attribute of action. Allah the Exalted said: "Nor do they find in their breasts a need of that which they have been given" and He the Mighty and Majestic said: "They wish that you would disbelieve as they have disbelieved, so you would be equal" and He said: "If good touches you, it distresses them." As for the action, it is backbiting and lying, and it is an act emanating from envy (Hasad) and is not the essence of envy (Hasad). Rather, the place of envy (Hasad) is the heart (Qalb), not the limbs. Indeed, this envy (Hasad) is not an injustice requiring seeking permission for it, but it is a sin between you and Allah the Exalted. Seeking permission is only required for the apparent causes on the limbs. So if you restrain your outward appearance and oblige your heart (Qalb) along with that to dislike what naturally emanates from it of desiring the removal of the blessing, until it is as if you detest your soul (Nafs) for what is in its nature, so that dislike is from the side of the intellect in opposition to the inclination from the side of nature, then you have fulfilled what is obligatory upon you. a.g: Except for those who take refuge with a people between yourselves and whom is a treaty or those who come to you, their hearts strained at [the prospect of] fighting you or fighting their own people. And if Allah had willed, He could have given them power over you, and they would have fought you. So if they remove themselves from you and do not fight you and offer you peace, then Allah has not made for you a cause [for fighting] against them.

You will find others who wish to obtain security from you and [to] obtain security from their people. Every time they are returned to [the influence of] disbelief, they fall back into it. So if they do not withdraw from you or offer you peace or restrain their hands, then seize them and kill them wherever you overtake them. And those - We have made for you against them a clear authorization.

And never is it for a believer to kill a believer except by mistake. And whoever kills a believer by mistake - then the freeing of a believing slave and a compensation payment presented to the deceased's family [is required] unless they give [up their right as] charity. But if the deceased was from a people at war with you and he was a believer - then [only] the freeing of a believing slave; and if he was from a people with whom you have a treaty - then a compensation payment presented to his family and the freeing of a believing slave. And whoever does not find [one or cannot afford to buy one] - then [instead], a fast for two months consecutively, [seeking] acceptance of repentance from Allah. And Allah is ever Knowing and Wise.

But whoever kills a believer intentionally - his recompense is Hell, wherein he will abide eternally, and Allah has become angry with him and has cursed him and has prepared for him a great punishment.

And His saying, the Exalted: 'And whoever kills a believer intentionally, his recompense is Hell, abiding therein forever' (Quran 4:93). And these general statements are also specified by the evidence of His saying, the Exalted: 'And He forgives what is less than that for whom He wills' (Quran 4:48). So it is necessary that His will (Mashiyyah) remains for forgiving what is besides polytheism (Shirk). And likewise His saying, peace be upon him: 'He will exit from the Fire whoever has in his heart (Qalb) an atom's weight of faith (Iman).' And His saying, the Exalted: 'Indeed, We do not waste the reward of one who does good deeds (Ahsan 'Amalan)' (Quran 18:30). And His saying, the Exalted: 'Indeed, Allah does not waste the reward of the doers of good (Muhsinin)' (Quran 9:120). So how would He waste the reward of the foundation of faith (Iman) and all acts of obedience (TÄ'Ät) with a single act of disobedience (Ma'siyah)? And His saying, the Exalted: 'And whoever kills a believer intentionally' (Quran 4:93), meaning because of his faith (Iman), and it has come down for a reason like this.

And whoever is unveiled to these matters after becoming accustomed to status and familiarity with it, and it becomes firmly rooted in him through habit by directly engaging with its causes, then mere knowledge and unveiling are insufficient for treatment; rather, he must add to it action, and his action is in three matters: The first is that he flees from the place of status so that he does not witness its causes, making patience with the causes difficult for him, just as one flees from being overcome by desire from observing stimulating images. And whoever does not do this has disbelieved in the blessing of Allah in the vastness of the earth, as He, the Exalted, said: 'Was not the earth of Allah spacious that you might emigrate therein?' (Quran 4:97). The second is that he compels himself in his actions to deeds that contradict what he has become accustomed to, thus replacing affectation with simplicity and the attire of dignity with the attire of humility, and likewise every form, state, and action in dwelling, clothing, food, standing, and sitting that he used to practice in fulfillment of the requirements of his status, he should replace with their opposites until he becomes firmly rooted through habituation in the opposite of what he was previously rooted in through habituation of its opposite, for there is no meaning to treatment except opposition.

This indicates that whoever is afflicted with a land where sins abound and good is scarce has no excuse for remaining there; rather, he should emigrate. Allah the Exalted said: 'Was not the earth of Allah spacious so that you could emigrate therein?' If he is prevented from that by dependents or ties, he should not be content with his state, at ease in his Soul (Nafs) with it; rather, he should be disturbed in Heart (Qalb) about it, saying constantly: 'Our Lord, take us out of this town whose people are wrongdoers.' This is because when injustice becomes widespread, calamity descends and destroys everyone, encompassing the obedient. Allah the Exalted said: 'And fear a trial which will not strike those who have wronged among you exclusively.' Therefore, there is absolutely no absolute contentment in any of the causes of deficiency in religion except from the perspective of attributing them to the action of Allah the Exalted; as for them in themselves, there is no aspect of contentment with them in any state.

The ninth reason that prevents one from Devotion (Tajarrud) to Allah, so one prefers solitude (Ghurbah) and obscurity (Khumul) and avoids abundance (Saa'ah) and status (Jah), or like one who is called to innovation (Bid'ah) by force or to a position of work that is not permissible to engage in, so he seeks to flee from it. As for what is sought, it is either worldly like wealth and status, or religious (Dini), and the religious is either knowledge (Ilm) or action (Amal). Knowledge is either knowledge from the religious sciences, or knowledge of the character traits (Akhlaq) of his soul (Nafs) and its attributes (Sifat) by way of experience (Tajribah), or knowledge of the signs (Ayaat) of the earth and its wonders, like the journey of Dhul-Qarnayn and his traveling around the regions of the earth. Action is either worship (Ibadah) or visitation (Ziyarah), and worship is Hajj, Umrah, and Jihad. Visitation is also among the acts of nearness (Qurbat), and it may be intended for a place like Makkah, Madinah, Bayt al-Maqdis, and the frontiers (Thughur), for guarding (Ribat) them is an act of nearness. It may be intended for the saints (Awliya) and scholars (Ulama), and they are either dead, so their graves are visited, or alive, so one seeks blessing (Tabarruk) by seeing them, and from looking at their states (Ahwal), strength of desire (Raghbah) in following their example (Iqtida) is gained. These are the categories of journeys, and from this division emerge the categories of the first division: travel in seeking knowledge, which is either obligatory (Wajib) or supererogatory (Nafil), and that is according to whether the knowledge is obligatory or supererogatory. That knowledge is either knowledge of matters of his religion, or of his character traits in his soul, or of Allah's signs in His earth. And the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: 'Whoever leaves his house in seeking knowledge, he is in the path (Sabil) of Allah until he returns.' Hadith: 'Whoever leaves his house in seeking knowledge, he is in the path of Allah until he returns.' Reported by al-Tirmidhi from the hadith of Anas, and he said it is good (Hasan) and rare (Gharib). And in another report: 'Whoever treads a path in which he seeks knowledge, Allah will ease for him a path to Paradise.' Hadith: 'Whoever treads a path in which he seeks knowledge...' Reported by Muslim. And it preceded in knowledge. And Sa'id ibn al-Musayyab would travel days in seeking a single hadith. And al-Sha'bi said: 'If a man traveled from Syria to the farthest Yemen for a word that guides him to guidance (Huda) or turns him away from error (Radda), his journey would not be wasted.' And Jabir ibn Abd Allah traveled from Madinah to Egypt with ten of the Companions, and they traveled for a month in a hadith that reached them from Abd Allah Unays al-Ansari, that he narrated from the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), until they heard it. Hadith: 'Jabir ibn Abd Allah traveled from Madinah to a journey of a month in a hadith that reached him from Abd Allah ibn Unays.' Reported by al-Khatib in the book of travel (al-Rihlah) with a good chain (Isnad), and he did not name the Companion. And al-Bukhari said in his Sahih: 'Jabir ibn Abd Allah traveled a month's journey to Abd Allah ibn Unays for a single hadith.' And Ahmad reported it except he said to Syria, and its chain is good. And for Ahmad: 'Abu Ayyub rode to Uqbah ibn Amir to Egypt in a hadith.' And for him: 'Uqbah ibn Amir came to Salamah ibn Mukhallad while he was the governor of Egypt in another hadith.' And both are disconnected (Munqati), and every mentioned in knowledge is acquired for.

a.g: And when you travel throughout the land, there is no blame upon you for shortening the prayer, [especially] if you fear that those who disbelieve may disrupt [or attack] you. Indeed, the disbelievers are ever to you a clear enemy.

And when you are among them and lead them in prayer, let a group of them stand [in prayer] with you and let them carry their arms. And when they have prostrated, let them be [in position] behind you and have the other group come forward which has not [yet] prayed and let them pray with you, taking precaution and carrying their arms. Those who disbelieve wish that you would neglect your weapons and your baggage so they could come down upon you in one [single] attack. But there is no blame upon you, if you are troubled by rain or are ill, for putting down your arms, but take precaution. Indeed, Allah has prepared for the disbelievers a humiliating punishment.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Status and Ostentation
Indeed, the Qur'an [al-Qur'an], from its beginning to its end, is a warning [tahdhir] from Satan [al-Shaytan]. So how [can it be otherwise] when He has commanded caution from the enemy, just as He commanded caution from the disbelievers, saying, the Most High: "And let them take their precaution and their arms." So if it is incumbent upon you, by the command of Allah, to be cautious of the disbelieving enemy whom you see, then it is more incumbent upon you to be cautious of an enemy who sees you and you do not see him. Therefore, being occupied with Allah [al-istighlal bi-Allah] does not mean turning away from that which Allah has warned against, and by this, the doctrine of the second group is invalidated in their assumption that this detracts from trust [al-tawakkul]. For taking up the shield and weapon, gathering the troops, and digging the trench did not detract from the trust [tawakkul] of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, so how could fearing that which Allah has warned against and being cautious of that which He has commanded caution from detract from trust [al-tawakkul]? And We have mentioned in the Book of Trust [Kitab al-Tawakkul] what clarifies the error of those who claim that the meaning of trust [al-tawakkul] is to completely abandon means [al-asbab]. And His saying, the Most High: "And prepare against them whatever you are able of power and of steeds of war" does not contradict compliance with trust [al-tawakkul], as long as the heart [al-qalb] believes that the One who harms and benefits, the One who gives life and causes death, is Allah, the Most High. Likewise, one is cautious of Satan [al-Shaytan] while believing that the One who guides and leads astray is Allah, and sees the means [al-asbab] as subjugated intermediariesâ€”as We have mentioned in the Book of Trust [Kitab al-Tawakkul].

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Patience and Gratitude
And it should not be said that the one who turns away from the world is suffering through patience from it, for the one who inclines toward it is also suffering through patience upon it, and preserving it, and acquiring it, and repelling thieves from it. And the suffering of the one who turns away leads to pleasure in the Hereafter, and the suffering of the one who inclines leads to pain in the Hereafter. So let the one who turns away from the world recite to himself the saying of The Most High: 'And do not weaken in pursuit of the people; if you should be suffering, then indeed they are suffering as you are suffering, but you hope from Allah that which they do not hope.' So then, indeed the way of gratitude has been blocked upon the creation due to their ignorance of the varieties of blessings, the apparent and the hidden, the specific and the general.

Vol 2: Etiquette of Seclusion
And Al-Hasan ibn Ali (may Allah be pleased with them both) would pass by beggars while they had bread crumbs before them, and they would say: 'Come to lunch, O son of the Messenger of Allah.' So he would dismount, sit on the road, eat with them, then remount and say: 'Indeed Allah does not love the arrogant ones.' The second aspect is that the one who occupies his Soul (Nafs) with seeking people's pleasure about him and improving their opinion of him is deluded, because if he knew Allah with true knowledge, he would know that the creation cannot avail him anything from Allah, and that his harm and benefit are in Allah's hand, and there is no benefactor nor harmer except Him, and that whoever seeks people's pleasure and love with Allah's displeasure, Allah will be displeased with him and make people displeased with him. Rather, people's pleasure is an unattainable goal, so Allah's pleasure is more worthy of pursuit. Therefore, Al-Shafi'i said to Yunus ibn Abd al-A'la: 'By Allah, I only advise you: there is no way to safety from people, so look at what suits you and do it.' Therefore, it is said: 'Whoever watches people dies grieving, and the bold one attains pleasure.' And Sahl looked at one of his companions and said to him: 'Do such and such' regarding something he commanded him to do. He said: 'O master, I cannot do it because of people.' So he turned to his companions and said: 'A servant does not attain the reality of this matter until he is in one of two descriptions: a servant from whose eye people have fallen, so he sees in the world only his Creator, and that no one can harm him nor benefit him; and a servant whose Soul (Nafs) has fallen from his Heart (Qalb), so he does not care in what state they see him.' And Al-Shafi'i (may Allah have mercy on him) said: 'There is no one except that he has a lover and a hater, so if it is like this, then be with the people of Allah's obedience.' And it was said to Al-Hasan: 'O Abu Sa'id, there are people who attend your gathering whose only aim is to follow...'

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Love, Longing, and Intimacy
For whoever knows his self (Nafs) and knows his Lord (Rabb) knows with certainty that he has no existence from his own essence, and indeed the existence of his essence, the continuity of his existence, and the perfection of his existence are from Allah, to Allah, and by Allah. He is the Creator (Al-Khaliq) who brings him into existence, He is the Sustainer who preserves him, and He is the Perfecter of his existence by creating attributes of perfection and creating the means that lead to Him, possessing the creation of guidance to utilize the means. Otherwise, the servant (Al-'Abd) from the perspective of his essence has no existence from his essence; rather, he is pure effacement and sheer non-existence were it not for the grace (Fadl) of Allah, the Exalted, upon him with creation. And he would perish immediately after his existence were it not for the grace of Allah upon him with preservation. And he would be deficient after existence were it not for the grace of Allah upon him with the completion of his creation. In summary, there is nothing in existence that has self-subsistence by itself except the Self-Subsisting (Al-Qayyum), the Living (Al-Hayy), who is self-subsistent by His essence, and everything other than Him is subsistent by Him. If the knower (Al-'Arif) loves his essence and the existence of his essence is derived from another, then by necessity he loves the one who benefits his existence and perpetuates it, if he knows Him as Creator, Originator, Inventor, Preserver, Self-Subsistent by Himself, and Sustainer of others. If he does not love Him, it is due to his ignorance of his self and his Lord. Love (Al-Mahabbah) is the fruit of knowledge (Al-Ma'rifah), so it ceases with its absence, weakens with its weakness, and strengthens with its strength. Therefore, Al-Hasan Al-Basri, may Allah have mercy on him, said: 'Whoever knows his Lord loves Him, and whoever knows the world renounces it.' How can it be conceived that a human loves his self and does not love his Lord by whom his self subsists? It is known that the one afflicted by the heat of the sun, since he loves the shade, loves by necessity the trees by which the shade subsists. And everything in existence in relation to the power of Allah, the Exalted, is like the shade in relation to the tree and the light in relation to the sun, for all are from the effects of His power, and the existence of all follows His existence, just as the existence of light follows the sun and the existence of shade follows the tree. And the occupation of the Companions and the Followers (may Allah be pleased with them) was in five things: reciting the Quran, building mosques, the Remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah the Exalted, commanding good (Ma'ruf), and forbidding evil (Munkar). This is because they heard from his saying (peace be upon him): 'Every speech of the son of Adam is against him, not for him, except three: commanding good, forbidding evil, or the Remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah the Exalted.' And Allah the Exalted said: 'There is no good in much of their secret counsels except for one who enjoins charity or good (Ma'ruf) or reconciliation between people... the verse' (An-Nisa:114). And some scholars saw some of the people of opinion from the people of Kufa in a dream and said: 'What did I see in what I was upon of giving legal opinions (Fatwa) and opinion?' So he disliked his face and turned away from him and said: 'We did not find it anything, and we did not praise its safety.' And Ibn Husain said: 'Indeed, one of them gives a legal opinion in a matter that if it were presented to Umar ibn al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him), he would gather for it the people of Badr.' And silence has remained the practice of the people of knowledge except in necessity.

Vol 2: Enjoining Good and Forbidding Evil
And Allah the Exalted said: 'There is no good in much of their secret counsels except for one who enjoins charity or good (ma'ruf) or reconciliation between people. And whoever does that seeking the pleasure (mardat) of Allah, then We will give him a great reward.' And Allah the Exalted said: 'And if two parties of the believers fight, then make peace between them...' The reconciliation is a prohibition (nahy) against aggression and a restoration to obedience. a.g: And whoever does righteous deeds, whether male or female, while being a believer - those will enter Paradise and will not be wronged, [even as much as] the speck on a date seed.

And who is better in religion than one who submits himself to Allah while being a doer of good and follows the religion of Abraham, inclining toward truth? And Allah took Abraham as an intimate friend.
And to Allah belongs whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth. And ever is Allah, of all things, encompassing.

And they request from you, [O Muhammad], a [legal] ruling concerning women. Say, "Allah gives you a ruling about them and [about] what has been recited to you in the Book concerning the orphan girls to whom you do not give what is decreed for them - and [yet] you desire to marry them - and concerning the oppressed among children and that you maintain for orphans [their rights] in justice." And whatever you do of good - indeed, Allah is ever Knowing of it.

And if a woman fears from her husband contempt or evasion, there is no sin upon them if they make terms of settlement between them - and settlement is best. And present in [human] souls is stinginess. But if you do good and fear Allah - then indeed Allah is ever, with what you do, Acquainted.

And you will never be able to be equal [in feeling] between wives, even if you should strive [to do so]. So do not incline completely [toward one] and leave another hanging. And if you amend [your affairs] and fear Allah - then indeed, Allah is ever Forgiving and Merciful.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 2: Etiquette of Marriage
And indeed upon him is justice in giving and overnight stay, but as for in love and sexual intercourse, that does not enter under choice. Allah the Exalted said (And you will never be able to be just between women even if you should strive [to do so]), meaning that you be just in the desire of the heart (Qalb) and inclination of the soul (Nafs), and following that is the disparity in sexual intercourse. And the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, (would be just between them in giving and staying overnight in the nights and would say: O Allah, this is my effort in what I possess, and I have no capability in what You possess and I do not possess)[131] meaning love. And indeed Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, was the most beloved of his wives to him[132], and his other wives knew that. And he would be carried around in his illness every day and every night, staying overnight with each one of them, and he would say: Where am I tomorrow? Then one of his women perceived that and said: He is only asking about the day of Aisha. So they said: O Messenger of Allah, we have permitted you to be in the house of Aisha, for it is difficult upon you to be carried every night. So he said: And have you consented to that? They said: Yes. He said: Then move me to the house of Aisha[133]. And whenever one woman gives her night to her companion and the husband consents to that, the right is established for her.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Anger and Envy
Whoever's anger (ghadab) inclines toward weakness until he feels from his soul (nafs) a deficiency in protective jealousy (ghayrah) and baseness of the soul (nafs) in enduring humiliation and oppression in its improper place, he should treat his soul (nafs) until his anger (ghadab) strengthens. And whoever's anger (ghadab) inclines toward excess until it drags him to recklessness and plunging into abominations, he should treat his soul (nafs) to reduce from the intensity of anger (ghadab) and stand upon the true middle between the two extremes; it is the Straight Path (al-Sirat al-Mustaqim) and it is finer than a hair and sharper than a sword; so if he is incapable of it, let him seek proximity to it. Allah the Exalted said: "And you will never be able to be just between women, even if you should strive [to do so]. So do not incline completely [toward one] and leave another hanging. And if you amend [your affairs] and fear Allah, then indeed Allah is ever Forgiving and Merciful." So not everyone who is incapable of bringing all good should bring all evil; but some evil is lighter than some, and some good is higher than some. This is the reality of anger (ghadab) and its degrees. We ask Allah for good success in what pleases Him; indeed He is over all things competent.

a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 2: Etiquette of Marriage
The intention from this is to clarify that divorce is permissible, and Allah has promised wealth in both separation and marriage. He said: 'And marry the unmarried among you and the righteous among your male slaves and female slaves. If they should be poor, Allah will enrich them from His bounty.' And He, the Exalted, said: 'And if they separate, Allah will enrich each from His abundance.'

Indeed, and He, the Exalted, said: "And if they separate, Allah will enrich each from His abundance [sa'at]." And Allah the Exalted has specifically attributed piety (Taqwa) to Himself, saying: 'Neither their flesh nor their blood reaches Allah, but what reaches Him is piety (Taqwa) from you.' {} And indeed piety (Taqwa) is an expression of restraint due to fear (Khauf) as previously mentioned, and therefore He said: 'Indeed, the most noble of you with Allah is the most pious (Atqakum) among you.' {} And therefore Allah the Exalted enjoined the former and the latter with piety (Taqwa), saying: 'And We have enjoined those who were given the Scripture before you and you yourselves to fear Allah (Taqwa).' {} And He the Mighty and Majestic said: 'And fear Me, if you are believers.' {} So He commanded fear (Khauf) and made it obligatory and a condition in faith (Iman), therefore it is inconceivable that a believer (Mu'min) be free from fear (Khauf), even if weak, and the weakness of his fear (Khauf) is according to the weakness of his knowledge (Ma'rifah) and faith (Iman).

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Foundations of Belief
The first aspect: That which is not based on opposing doubt is the caution from certainty out of fear of what it contains of self-praise (Tazkiyah). Allah the Exalted said: 'So do not claim purity for yourselves' {} and said: 'Have you not seen those who claim purity for themselves?' {} and Allah the Exalted said: 'See how they invent lies against Allah' {} and it was said to a wise man: 'What is ugly truth?' He said: 'A person's praise of himself.' And Faith (Iman) is from the highest attributes of glory, and certainty is absolute self-praise, and the formula of exception is like a burden for one who recognizes self-praise, just as when it is said to a person: 'Are you a doctor or jurist or exegete?' and he says: 'Yes, if Allah wills,' not in the context of doubt but to remove himself from praising himself. So the formula is one of hesitation and weakening of the report itself, and its meaning is the weakening required by the implications of the report, which is self-praise. By this interpretation, if asked about a blameworthy description, exception would not be appropriate. The second aspect: The etiquette of mentioning Allah the Exalted in every situation and referring all matters to the will (Mashiyyah) of Allah the Exalted, for Allah the Exalted disciplined His Prophet ï·º, so He said: 'And never say of anything, "Indeed, I will do that tomorrow," except [when adding], "If Allah wills."' {} and He said: 'O you who have believed, believe in Allah and His Messenger and the Book which He sent down upon His Messenger and the Scripture which He sent down before. And whoever disbelieves in Allah, His angels, His books, His messengers, and the Last Day has certainly gone far astray.' So He made Faith (Iman) subject to the will (Mashiyyah), and thus our saying 'We have believed in Allah and what has been revealed to us, if Allah wills' should be.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Love, Longing, and Intimacy
Therefore, the beauty of the attributes of the Truthful Ones (Al-Siddiqin) whom hearts naturally love returns to three matters: The first is their knowledge of Allah and His angels and His books and His messengers and the laws of His prophets. The second: their ability to reform themselves and reform the servants of Allah through guidance and governance. The third: their purity from vices, impurities, and overwhelming desires that divert from the paths of good and attract to the way of evil, and by this the prophets, scholars, caliphs, and kings who are people of justice and generosity are loved, so relate these attributes to the attributes of Allah. As for knowledge: Where is the knowledge of the first and the last compared to the knowledge of Allah which encompasses everything with an encompassing beyond limit, such that not an atom's weight in the heavens or the earth escapes Him? And He addressed all creation, saying, exalted is He: "And you have not been given of knowledge except a little." Rather, if the people of the earth and the heavens gathered to encompass His knowledge and wisdom in the details of the creation of an ant or a mosquito, they would not attain a tenth of a tenth of that. "And they encompass not a thing of His knowledge except by what He wills." And the small amount that all creatures know, they know it by His teaching, as Allah said: "He created man, taught him eloquence." If the beauty and nobility of the knowledgeable one is a beloved matter and it is in itself an adornment and perfection attributed to him, then it is not fitting to love for this reason except Allah. The knowledge of the scholars is ignorance in comparison to His knowledge. Rather, whoever knows the most knowledgeable person of his time and the most ignorant person of his time, it becomes impossible for him to be ignorant that the knowledge of Allah is not encompassed by anyone, and that no one knows from His knowledge except what Allah has taught him. And this is the meaning of His saying, exalted is He: "O you who have believed, believe in Allah and His Messenger and the Book which He sent down upon His Messenger and the Scripture which He sent down before. And whoever disbelieves in Allah, His angels, His books, His messengers, and the Last Day has certainly strayed into far error." For He commanded belief in Allah, His angels, His books, His messengers, and the Last Day, and this is the knowledge by which the Truthful Ones are adorned. So whoever does not believe in this has certainly strayed into far error.

Give tidings to the hypocrites that there is for them a painful punishment -
